repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Second Bank Restructuring Facility
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was highly likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that the
            financial sector adjustment operations need to be based on
            prior economic and sector work. Financial sector adjustment
            operations should set limited objectives. Over-ambitious
            objectives such as the restoration of the solvency and
            soundness of the banking system are long-term goals that go
            beyond a single operation. Bank restructuring operations
            should disburse against the completed resolution of specific
            bank cases, not against the promise of future actions which
            may not materialize. Ensure that the main implementing
            agency is the main recipient of the Bank resources. Bank
            funds should benefit the main agency in charge of
            implementing the policy reforms, to strengthen the
            incentives of these agencies to work in close collaboration
            with the Bank.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Second Bank Restructuring Facility
            Adjustment Loan Project : Release of the Third Tranche -
            waiver of one condition

abstracts.cdata!:
This document summarizes progress in
            implementing the Program, and reports on actions taken by
            the Government of Mexico to meet specific conditions for the
            release of the Third Tranche. Waiver for the condition of
            the Regulatory Reform Program, as contained in the
            agreements is sought on the grounds set therein. Based on
            the assessment that: a) the National Banking and Securities
            Commission (CNBV), and the Ministry of Finance (SHCP) have
            approved other important new prudential rules that
            contribute to improving the health, and stability of the
            financial sector; and, b) the Asset Disposal Program, and
            the Bank Resolution Program have been implemented on a
            consistent basis with the implementation letter, exceeding
            the minimum requirements for compliance, this memorandum
            recommends that a waiver be granted with respect to the
            pending conditions, and the Third Tranche be released. The
            Project supports the Government of Mexico's second
            phase of its Bank Restructuring Program, which includes up
            front measures to improve the legal and regulatory
            framework, for a safer operation of the Mexican financial
            sector, and the sale, merger or liquidation of the remaining
            insolvent banks under government control. Compliance with
            the tranche release conditions is discussed, specifying
            actions under the Regulatory Reform Program - amendment to
            the rules applicable to external audit reports, and
            introduction of new rules to regulate the risk of banking
            operations through the internet - have not been met.
            However, given that the National Banking and Securities
            Commission (CNBV) has issued other important new regulatory
            rules that contribute to strengthening the governance in the
            banking sector, a waiver of compliance with the Third
            Tranche requirements, is justified.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Second Bank Restructuring Facility
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Bank Restructuring Facility
            Adjustment Loan Project will assist the Government of
            Mexico, implement its Bank Restructuring Program, aimed at
            improving a banking sector, capable to withstand external
            shocks, and to improve lending to the private sector. The
            project will support additional legal, and regulatory
            reforms, to strengthen governance in the banking sector,
            extend the new capital, and credit portfolio classification
            regulations to public banks, and, provide an early warning
            system. It will also involve the resolution of the remaining
            banks under the Bank Savings Protection Institute's
            (IPAB) purview, which includes the restructuring, and
            sale/liquidation of Bancrecer, and liquidation of seven
            smaller intervened banks. Funding will help finance part of
            IPAB's debt-servicing needs arising from the
            implementation of its bank resolution program, complementing
            other sources of funds available to IPAB, such as fiscal
            transfers, proceeds from asset disposal/recovery, and fees
            from deposit insurance premiums. Although the project will
            be beneficial in reducing the potential repeat of the
            1994/95 banking crisis, risks include IPAB's limited
            ability to refinance its debt, potentially facing increased
            limitations in its capacity to capitalize and sell, or
            unwind and liquidate, troubled banks. Moreover, IPAB's
            large debt issues associated with the resolution process,
            could imply higher, volatile interest rates than otherwise.
            Nonetheless, the transactional nature of the loan
            disbursements, and its legal monitoring, would reduce those risks.
